Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2009 06:44PM michellehb wrote: My story is very similar, but I'm on the other side of the fence. My BC was also likely caused by my radiation for Hodgkins at 13 yrs old, 33 years ago. I was told the same, not a candidate for radiation, so I did the double mastectomy even though my BC was only in 1 breast. My dx (4/14/2009) was IDC, 2cm, Stage 2a, Grade 3, 2/14 nodes, ER+/PR+/HER2-. I did 4 cycles of Cytoxan/Adriamycin (started 6/25/2009), and now doing 4 cycles of Taxol, and possibly Avastin on a clinical trial. My radiological onc said radiation is a gray area. If your nodes were negative, then no question, no radiation. With 1-3 positive nodes there's research that suggests there is benefit with more radiation. But there's also risk, my radiological onc says, with increased chance of lymphadema and tiercery cancers, like leukemia. Since I only had a small amount of cancer in those 2 nodes, he's leaning toward no radiation. If you google, you can find the stats, which scares me about not getting it, though can't say I'd look forward to the radiation again.

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2009 12:34PM michellehb wrote: I would hug you too, we need hugs! My head is swimming too. My breast surgeon and oncs told me I need to be aggressive with + nodes and grade 3. I got 2 opionions, and 2 quotes on recurrence if I did nothing - 30 and 52 pct. Both are too high. With chemo of ACT +  tamoxofen, it's more like 20 pct. I think adding radiation knocks off a few more points, but not much. Not as good as my Hodgkins odds, but something I got to live with it. One of my issues is that I had the radiation at such a young age. Chemo was also not part of the protocol at the time, so the radiation dosage was big. I have to figure that I wouldn't have gotten BC w/out radiation. My radiation onc put it into perspective for me, though. He told me Hodgkins used to be very deadly before deep penetrating radiation was invented. It bought me the 33 years, and now I will fight again! Thank god for all the advances with BC that our odds are good. My sis is unfortunately battling ovarian cancer where the outlook is grim. And get the irony, she has the BRAC1 gene, and I do not. You can' tell me radiation wasn't a factor here! I'm sorry that you are not so happy with your oncs. I'm being treated at Northwestern in Chicago and can give you other names if it's anywhere near you.  It's really nice to have someone to share with - thanks for writing back.

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2010 07:05PM michellehb wrote: My experience was very similar to Otters. In my case, also no history of BC in the family, but my sister, who I recently lost, had ovarian cancer. In my case I was negative, but here's the irony, both sisters got the gene. If families are small sometimes it just doesn't show up. I found the advice quite helpful, especially since it factors into decisions I have to make, like whether I need to remove my ovaries.
